questions.text:
A couple presented to the infertility clinic as they have been unable to conceive for more than a year. The lady has no abnormalities in her laboratory reports. The semen analysis report of her husband is given below. Which of the following findings indicates a diagnosis of asthenospermia?

Appearance: Opalescent
Volume: 2 mL
pH: 7.5
Fructose: present
Sperm concentration: 14 million/mL
Morphology: 35% normal
Motility: 20% motile
No sperm agglutination was seen.
questions.solution:
The semen analysis finding of 20% motility (option B) indicates a diagnosis of asthenospermia.

Asthenospermia refers to decreased sperm motility. Normally, at least 50% of them should show progressive motility. Causes of asthenospermia include prolonged abstinence, anti-sperm antibodies, a genital tract infection, or varicocele.

Various semen abnormalities include:

An acidic pH or lack of fructose: indicates an obstruction in the efferent ductal system.

A low semen volume reflects incomplete specimen collection, short abstinence interval, partial vas deferens obstruction, or retrograde ejaculation.

Oligospermia is defined by a sperm concentration of <15 million/mL, concentrations of <5 million/mL are considered severe oligospermia.

Azoospermia (absence of sperm in semen) occurs due to outflow tract obstruction as a result of congenital absence of vas deferens, infection, vasectomy, or non-obstructive causes like testicular failure.

Teratospermia or teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: Identify the finding in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the foetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

If this part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os, the condition is called vasa previa. In this condition, rupture of the membranes leads to vaginal bleeding and foetal exsanguination.

Other options:

  • Battledore placenta – The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta - The foetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.
  • Succenturiate placenta - One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: While examining a patient with 12 weeks of amenorrhea who presented with vomiting and vaginal bleeding, you find that the cervical os is open and that the uterus is 16 weeks in size. The patient also has abnormally high levels of serum β-hCG (>1 lakh mIU/mL). Which of the following is likely to be seen on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with 12 weeks of amenorrhea, vaginal bleeding, and large-for-date uterus, with abnormally elevated HCG levels points towards a diagnosis of molar pregnancy, and a snowstorm appearance is characteristically seen on ultrasound in such cases. It is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

A molar pregnancy occurs due to the fusion of one sperm with an empty ovum or the fusion of 2 sperms simultaneously with an ovum. It may present with bleeding per vaginum or an acute discharge of vesicular mass per vaginum. On examination, the uterine size is more than the corresponding period of amenorrhea. It shows a characteristic snowstorm appearance on USG. 

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

  • Complete moles occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes. In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46,XX karyotype. In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46,XX, or 46,XY.
  • Partial moles occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms. The karyotype is usually triploid (69,XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92,XXXY). It is associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but is not associated with choriocarcinoma.

The definitive management after diagnosis is suction and evacuation, after making the cervix favorable. 

The given images show the development of hydatiform mole and snowstorm appearance on USG, respectively:

 

Other options:

Option A: Necklace appearance on ultrasound is seen in polycystic ovary disease. Multiple cysts (12 or more) of 2–9 mm size are located peripherally along the surface of the ovary, giving it this appearance. It is shown in the image below:


Option B: Ring-of-fire appearance is seen on color Doppler in ectopic pregnancy on the periphery of the adnexal mass. It is shown in the image below:

 

Option D: Double decidual sac sign on ultrasound is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac. It is shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text:
Match the following patients with Uterine prolapse with their best treatment option.
                 Age/condition       Management

1. Nulliparous women with a desire for future pregnancy

i. Fothergill's operation 
2. 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy ii. Cervicopexy
3. 30-year-old in puerperal period iii. Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair
4. 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation. iv. Ring pessary
questions.solution:
1-ii, 2-iii, 3-iv, 4-i (Option C) is correct. 

          Age/condition       Management

1) Nulliparous women with a desire for future pregnancy

ii.  Cervicopexy

2) 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy

iii.  Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

3) 30-year-old in puerperial period

 iv.  Ring pessary 

4) 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.

i.  Fothergill's operation

Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing functions. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in the puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Fothergill's repair, also known as Manchester's operation, is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix, and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence, leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence, subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.  

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function 

 

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: A 38-year-old multigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presented to the outpatient department with a history of painless vaginal bleeding. On examination, there is a fall in fetal heart rate when the fetal head is pushed into the pelvis. Identify the true statement about the condition associated with the sign described.

choices.text: Transabdominal sonography is the most accurate method of assessment.
MR imaging has replaced sonography in diagnosis.
Per vaginal examination should be avoided.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of painless vaginal bleeding with positive Stallworthy's sign is suggestive of placenta previa and the true statement associated with it is per vaginal examination should be avoided, as it can lead to torrential hemorrhage.

Stallworthy's sign refers to the slowing of the fetal heart rate when the head is pressed down into the pelvis. It recovers as soon as the pressure is released. It is suggestive of the presence of a low-lying placenta, particularly if located on the posterior wall of the uterus. 

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. 

Common risk factors for placenta previa include

  • Previous cesarian section
  • Myomectomy
  • Advanced maternal age (>35 years)
  • Smoking
  • multiple gestation
  • Multiparity
  • Prior curettage

Diagnosis :

  • Transabdominal sonography: A quick and accurate localization can be accomplished if the placenta clearly overlies the cervix or if it lies away from the lower uterine segment. Its limitations include:
    • Poor visualization in obese women
    • A full bladder may give a false impression that the placenta is overlying the cervix.
  • Transvaginal sonography: The most accurate method to assess the placental location. It is not contraindicated in placenta previa and is safe even when there is bleeding.
  • MRI: Localizes placental location excellently, gold standard but does not replace sonography in routine diagnosis.
  • In case of inconclusive USG reports or USG revealed type 1 placenta, a vaginal examination is done in operation theatre under anesthesia. This is done with preparation for an immediate cesarean section. 

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment.

  • Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Note: For clinical purpose, the types are graded into,

  • Mild degree (Type-I and II anterior) and
  • Major degree (Type-II posterior, III, and IV).

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida who presented with 6 weeks of amenorrhea was diagnosed to be a case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following would be a contraindication to expectant management in her?

choices.text: Presence of fetal heartbeat on transvaginal ultrasound
Absence of evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS
Serum β-HCG level of 300 IU/L and a falling trend

questions.solution:
In the case of ectopic pregnancy, the presence of a fetal heartbeat on transvaginal ultrasound is a contraindication for expectant management.

A gestational sac of 3 cm with no fetal cardiac activity, falling levels of serum β-HCG (with an initial level less than 1500 IU/L), and no symptoms are indications for expectant management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. It is done only in selected cases of asymptomatic women who are well-counseled and willing for subsequent follow-up visits.

Management of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy:

  1. Expectant management
  2. Conservative management
    • Medical 
    • Surgical
Expectant management Medical management Surgical management

An observation with serum β-HCG monitoring.

 Systemic use or direct local use of chemotherapeutic drugs- 
  • Drugs used: Methotrexate (MTX 50 mg/m2 single dose intramuscularly), potassium chloride, prostaglandin, hyperosmolar glucose, actinomycin.
  • Regular monitoring of serum β-HCG.

laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy, microsurgical laparotomy 

 

Indications:

  • Initial serum hCG level <1,500 IU/L and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • Gestation sac size less than 4 cm.
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS. 
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS.
  • Hemodynamically stable

Indications:

  • Patient is hemodynamically stable
  • Serum hCG level less than 5,000 IU/L
  • Tubal diameter less than 4 cm without any fetal cardiac activity
  • Absence of any intra-abdominal hemorrhage

 

Indications:

  • Cases that do not fit the medical therapy criteria
  • Serum β-HCG levels are elevated despite medical therapy
  • Persistence of fetal cardiac activity

 

 

Estimation of serum β-HCG should be done weekly till the value becomes less than 5.0 mlU/mL, following conservative surgery or medical treatment.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Auvard speculum. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall during vaginal hysterectomy and is self retractory due to the circular structure on its handle which is heavy.

The image given below shows Sim's speculum.

The image given below shows Cusco's self retaining bivalved speculum.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic. You do a bimanual examination by placing 2 fingers of one hand in the anterior fornix of the vagina and fingers of the other hand, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. This is called :
questions.solution:
The scenario described in the question is the demonstration of Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: the examiner performs a bimanual examination. Two fingers of one hand are placed in the anterior fornix of the vagina and fingers of the other hand are placed, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal fingers and the vaginal fingers appear to oppose each other below the body of the uterus. This can be elicited between 6-10 weeks.

This sign is based on the fact that the lower part of the body of the uterus is empty and extremely soft, and the upper part is enlarged by the growing fetus.

Other options :

Option A - Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination. It is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C - Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D - Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation presents with watery discharge per vagina and regular contractions. Physical examination reveals an adequately dilated and effaced cervix with rupture of membranes. Presentation is vertex, but labor stops progressing after the head has appeared in the vulva.  Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist in the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen maneuver can be used to assist with the delivery of the head in normal labor.

When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm, a gloved hand may be used for supporting the perineum in order to avoid expulsive delivery and to avoid perineal lacerations.

If the expulsive efforts are inadequate, the Ritgen maneuver is employed for assisted delivery of the head. This is accomplished by pushing the chin upward with the fingers of the right hand (positioned over the anococcygeal region), while the left hand exerts pressure on the occiput. Hence, the head is delivered by extension. 

The image below demonstrates the Ritgen maneuver:

 

Other options-

Option (A): Pinard maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of frank breech delivery.

Frank breech delivery (Pinard’s maneuver)—is done by intrauterine manipulation to convert a frank breech to a footing breech. Pinard maneuver is usually performed when the membranes have ruptured recently.

Technique:

  • The middle and index fingers are carried up to the popliteal fossa.
  • Then press and abduct the popliteal fossa so as to flex the fetal leg
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction and breech extraction is accomplished.

 

Option (B): Lovset maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

This technique is demonstrated in the images below-

 

Option (C): Modified Prague’s maneuver(shown below) is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: What is the condition seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows conjoined twins with fusion in the pelvic region, which is known as ischiopagus.

In monochorionic monoamniotic twinning, incomplete duplication of the embryonic disc can occur. Incomplete separation of the monozygotic twins results in the birth of two infants that are joined or fused together at some part of the body. These twins are known as conjoined twins or Siamese twins.

Depending on the degree of incomplete separation, different types of conjoined twins can form:

  • Craniopagus: United at the head
  • Thoracopagus: United at the thorax 
  • Cephalothoracopagus: Fusion of both head and thorax
  • Omphalopagous or Xiphipagous: United anteriorly from the xiphoid to the umbilicus
  • Parapagus: Lateral fusion with two heads, sharing a single thorax, abdomen, and pelvis (most common)
  • Ischiopagus: United at the pelvis 
  • Pygopagus: United in the sacral region
  • Heteropagous: Asymmetric forms

questions.text: Ultrasound of a 24-year-old primigravida at 20 weeks of gestation shows the presence of a single umbilical artery. No other gross fetal anomalies were detected.  Which of the following is true regarding this finding?

choices.text: It is an indicator of increased risk of malformations of the fetus
Equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers

questions.solution:
A single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. It indicates an increased risk of congenital malformations in the fetus.

A single umbilical artery is seen in the following conditions: 

  • Twin pregnancy
  • Gestational diabetes/Overt diabetes
  • Epilepsy
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage 

It is frequently associated with congenital malformations of the fetus (20–25%) such as:

  • Cardiovascular anomalies
  • Genitourinary anomalies
  • Trisomy 18

It increases the risks of adverse obstetric outcomes like:

  • Abortion
  • Fetal aneuploidy
  • Prematurity
  • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Perinatal mortality

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the placental separation method shown in the image below:

choices.text: It is commonly known as Schultz method
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva
It is an abnormal method of placental separation

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Mathews-Duncan method of placental separation where the maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labour. There are two normal mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

Schultze method:

  • The separation begins at the centre of the placenta (fetal surface). Hence, this is the first part to descend and appear at vulva.
  • The blood collects into a membranous sac behind the placenta, leading to the formation of retroplacental clot.
  • Bleeding does not occur until the placenta is completely extruded.

Mathews-Duncan method:

  • The separation of the placenta begins at the peripheral edge of the placenta. Hence, the maternal surface appears first.
  • The blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall, and escapes out from the vagina. There is no formation of retroplacental clot and the bleeding is profuse in this method of placental separation.
  • It is much less common than Schultze method.

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Signs of placental separation: 

  • The uterus becomes globular, firm and ballottable (earliest sign to appear).
  • Schroeder's sign: Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower segment and uterus rests over it. 
  • Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.
  • Kustner's sign: On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no longer recedes.
  • A sudden gush of blood
  • Permanent lengthening of the cord.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: The finding shown in the image is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows perihepatic adhesion which is seen in pelvic inflammatory disease.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is a perihepatitis which occurs in the setting of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It occurs in approximately 10 percent of women with acute PID.

Gonococcal salpingits/ chlamydial infection → transperitoneal/ vascular spread→ inflammation of the liver capsule and peritoneal surfaces of the anterior right upper quadrant.

Characterized by right upper quadrant abdominal pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder.

The image given represents the violin-string adhesions of chronic Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

questions.text: Among the following women with bleeding per vaginum (PV) who are being evaluated, which would be diagnosed as secondary PPH?

choices.text: A 32 year old woman at 40 weeks gestation with spotting PV
A 26 year old woman who delivered twins vaginally 6 hours ago
A 29 year old woman who delivered a preterm baby 1 week ago
A 36 year old woman at 32 weeks gestation bleeding PV and pain

questions.solution:
Secondary PPH occurs beyond 24 hours and within puerperium. The only patient who fits this is patient C, who delivered a preterm baby 1 week ago and now has bleeding PV.

Causes of secondary PPH include: Retained bits of membranes, infection, endometritis, etc.

Other Options:

Options A and D: These women have antepartum haemorrhage. (APH): Bleeding after 28 weeks but before birth of the baby.

Option B: This woman has primary PPH: Bleeding within 24 hours following birth of the baby.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient has completed a family and wanted a sterilization technique which can be surgically reversible. The following method of sterilization was done as shown below.
questions.solution:
The sterilization technique which can be surgically reversible and shown in the image is the Pomeroy technique.

The Pomeroy method is the most popular technique of tubal ligation in which the fallopian tube is identified on each side and brought out through the incision. The middle portion is then formed into a loop, tied at the base and excised. 

It is surgically reversible and has a short hospitalization. 

Other options:

Option A: In Uchida's method, the serosa in the midsegment of the tube is stripped off from the mucosa and then excised. The proximal segment is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimum tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty. 

Option B: The technique of fimbriectomy is irreversible. In this method, fimbria is excised. Thus, it is a permanent method of sterilisation. 

Option D: In Irving's procedure, the mid-portion of the tube is ligated with excision of the intervening portion. The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible method and may require a laparotomy incision.

The below image shows Pomeroy technique

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman on combined oral contraceptive pills is diagnosed with cholelithiasis for which an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy is planned. What would you advise her about the usage of these pills before the surgery?

choices.text: Stop using pills 2 weeks before surgery
Stop using pills one day before surgery
Stop using pills 4 weeks before surgery

questions.solution:
Usage of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) can be continued to the day of surgery and in the peri-operative period.

Estrogens are found to increase thromoembolic risk in patients. But modern oral contraceptives contain low amounts of estrogen. In this scenario, the risk of accidental pregnancy outweighs the significance of not taking the contraceptives prior to surgery. So, oral contraceptives can be continued. Estrogens must be discontinued only if the patient is deemed high risk for post operative venous thromboembolism. 

Barrier methods can be used during this period to prevent unwanted pregnancies. In case of emergency surgeries in patients on combined OCPs or hormone replacement therapy, perioperative thromboprophylaxis should be started.

Contraindications of COCPs:

  • Cardiac disease, hypertension, smoker over 35 years.
  • Diabetes.
  • History of thrombosis, myocardial infarct, sickle cell anemia, severe migraine.
  • Chronic liver diseases such as cholestatic jaundice of pregnancy, cirrhosis of the liver, adenoma, porphyrias.
  • Breast cancer, gall bladder disease.
  • Patient on enzyme-inducing drugs like rifampicin, and antiepileptic except sodium valproate.
  • Lactating woman.
  • Monilial vaginitis.

questions.text: In twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, an overdistended bladder and congestive cardiac failure are findings you would expect to see in:

choices.text: Recipient twin and donor twin, respectively
Donor twin and recipient twin, respectively

questions.solution:
An overdistended bladder and congestive cardiac failure are seen in the recipient twin in twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

Polyhydramnios (amniotic fluid index [AFI]: >25cm) and neural tube defects can be seen in any pregnancy, more so in pregnancies associated with diabetes mellitus and any form of multifetal pregnancy. Neural tube defects are also associated with folic acid deficiency. 

Selective growth restriction can also be seen in monochorionic twins, but it is a sequela to TTTS. Thus, the specific and the best answer to this question would be TTTS. 

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome:

TTTS is a type of fetal syndrome that can arise when monozygotic twinning results in two amnionic sacs and a common surrounding chorion. This leads to anatomical sharing of the two fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. It depends on the degree to which they are hemodynamically balanced. In those with significant pressure or flow gradients, a shunt will develop between fetuses. This chronic feto-fetal transfusion results in twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS).

In this syndrome, blood is transfused from a donor twin to its recipient sibling. This leads to the donor becoming anemic with restricted growth. On the contrary, the recipient may suffer from polycythemia and circulatory overload. This circulatory overload may manifest as hydrops.

Other features:

Donor twin  Recipient twin 
Oliguria Polyuria
Anemia Polycythemia
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Activation of renin-angiotensin system (RAAS) Activation of atrial natriuretic peptide
(ANP)
Decreased renal blood flow Increased renal blood flow
Non-visible bladder

Overdistended bladder
Renal failure

Congestive cardiac failure (CCF),
Circulatory overload, Hypertension  
 

Hydrops twin (late cases)
Hyperviscosity syndrome, Hyperbilirubinemia


The Quintero staging is as follows:  

  • Stage I: Amniotic fluid discordant + Urine visible in donor's bladder.
  • Stage II: Stage I + no visible urine in donor's bladder.
  • Stage III: Stage II + abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein.
  • Stage IV: Frank ascites or hydrops in either twin.
  • Stage V: Demise of either fetus.

Treatment:

  • Laser photoablation of the placental vascular anastomoses is the preferred treatment for severe TTTS—Quintero stages 2 to 4.
  • Septostomy is seldom done. 
  • Amnioreduction is a treatment modality that involves needle drainage of excessive amniotic fluid.
  • Selective feticide is done only if the growth disturbances develop before 20 weeks.
  • Of all, selective fetoscopic laser photocoagulation (SFLP) by Solomon technique is the preferred treatment modality as it is associated with better survival rates and a reduced likelihood of recurrence.

The donor twin is also known as pump twin / stuck twin, and the manifestation is termed as polyhydramnios -oligohydramnios syndrome or poly-oli syndrome. So, the incidences of isolated oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios in twins are rare. 

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A young woman with a previous history of dilatation and curettage for elective abortion presents with hypomenorrhea. Hysterosalpingography shows irregular, angulated filling defects. Which of the following investigations is used for the definitive diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asherman syndrome. Hysteroscopy is used for the definitive diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

Given below is an algorithm for the evaluation of amenorrhea.

Other options:

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasonography is a noninvasive imaging technique using the transvaginal approach. It provides a more detailed evaluation of the pelvic organs as compared to the transabdominal approach.

Option C: Saline infusion sonography is a procedure where normal saline is injected into the uterine cavity and the uterus is imaged with transvaginal sonography. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 43-year-old multiparous woman presented with menorrhagia and secondary dysmenorrhea. On examination, Halban's sign was positive. The transvaginal USG findings are given below. Which of the following is the definitive treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the transvaginal ultrasound(TVS) showing the Venetian blind appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. The definitive treatment for adenomyosis is hysterectomy.

Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical assessment. Painful, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus is suggestive of adenomyosis. On bimanual examination, the uterus is softened and tender. This is known as Halban's sign. 

TVS findings include salt and pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of subendometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

The image below is of a sagittal MRI showing a uterus with adenomyosis in the posterior wall. Gross enlargement of the posterior wall is noted, with many foci of hyperintensity.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in her 27th week of gestation is suspected to have gestational diabetes mellitus. Which of the following tests can be done to arrive at the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The glucose tolerance test is considered as the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

Diagnostic criteria with 75 g are as follows:

  • Fasting: 92 mg/dl 
  • 1hour: 180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hr: 153 mg/dl

Note: Earlier, a two-step approach was being used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result for this test were then subject to the second step, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. This has now been replaced by the one-step approach that omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

questions.text: What is the use of this instrument?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a Leech-Wilkinson cannula. It is used to inject dye in hysterosalpingography. 

The following images show the cannula placed in the cervix for the procedure:


Other cannula used for the same purpose is the Rubin’s cannula which is shown below:

questions.text: Banana and lemon signs are seen in which fetal anomaly?
questions.solution:
Signs of neural tube defect on targeted sonography:

  • Small biparietal diameter
  • Ventriculomegaly
  • Frontal bone scalloping or the lemon sign
  • Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna known as banana sign.

questions.text: The placenta shown in the image is associated with which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
The placenta shown in the image is the circumvallate placenta and it is associated with the complication of preterm delivery.

Circumvallate placenta:

Chorion periphery is a thickened, opaque, gray white circular ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Complications associated with circumvalate placenta:

  • Abortion
  • Antepartum hemorrhage
  • Hydrorrhea gravidarum
  • Intrauterine growth restriction
  • Preterm delivery
  • Retained placenta or membranes

In Succenturiate Placenta, accessory lobe can be retained causing subinvolution, sepsis, post-partum haemorrhage, and polyp formation.

questions.text: A female patient with twin pregnancies underwent an abdominal ultrasound. It showed that the upper part of the body of one fetus was absent and the other fetus was normal. The echo of the normal fetus was suggestive of congestive cardiac failure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP).

TRAP is a complication seen in monochorionic multifetal gestation. It is caused by a large artery-to-artery or vein-to-vein placental shunt. Here, the recipient twin lacks a cardiac system, while the donor twin does the work of supplying blood for both twins. Blood from the donor twin reaches the iliac vessels of the recipient twin through the umbilical arteries. Therefore, in the recipient twin, only the lower body is developed, while the upper body is poorly developed. The donor twin may show signs of heart failure.

Developmental abnormality in the recipient twin:

  • No identifiable structures - Acardius amorphous
  • Failure of head growth - Acardius acephalus
  • Partially developed head with identifiable limbs - Acardius myelacephalus

Other options: 

Option A- Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. After oxygenation, the blood is taken up by the recipient twin. The donor twin will have anemia and appears pale, while the recipient twin will have polycythemia and features of heart failure.

Option B- Twin anemia–polycythemia sequence (TAPS) is similar to TTTS, where the donor twin is pale and anemic, whereas the recipient twin is polycythemic. However, unlike the case with TTTS, the amniotic fluid volumes in TAPS are similar for both fetuses.

Option D- Twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome (TOPS) is seen in TTTS. The donor fetus becomes oliguric due to hypovolemia, and the recipient fetus develops increased urine output due to hypervolemia. This results in oligohydramnios in the donor and hydramnios in the recipient fetus.

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of excessive fatigue and palpitations. On examination, severe pallor and pedal edema are present with an oxygen saturation of 89%, and there is evidence of impending heart failure. Her hemoglobin is 5.9 g/dL. Which among the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient is packed cell transfusion.

The treatment of choice for anemia with hemoglobin between 5-7 g/dL at <34 weeks period of gestation with hypoxia and impending signs of heart failure like pedal edema is packed cell transfusion. Only packed cell transfusions are carried out and about 80-100 mL of blood is infused at a time and repeated only after 24 hours. 

The following precautions are taken prior to blood transfusions:

  • Administration of antihistaminics intramuscularly
  • Administration of diuretics intramuscularly at least 2 hours prior to transfusion to produce negative fluid balance
  • Adjustment of the drip rate to 10 drops/minute
  • Observation of the pulse, respiration, and basal lung crepitations

The complications of blood transfusions include premature labor, increased chances of worsening cardiac failure, and transfusion reactions.

Following are the RCOG guidelines for initiating blood transfusion during pregnancy:

  • Antepartum period
    1. Pregnancy <34 weeks:
      1. Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
    2. Pregnancy >34 weeks:
      1. Hb <7 g/dL even without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Severe anemia with decompensation
    3. Anemia not due to hematinic deficiency:
      1. Hemoglobinopathy or bone marrow failure syndromes
      2. Consult hematologist
    4. Acute hemorrhage:
      1. Always indicated if Hb <6 g/dL
      2. If the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing hemorrhage
  • Intrapartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. The decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms
  • Postpartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. Anemia with signs of shock/acute hemorrhage with signs of hemodynamic instability

Other options given are parenteral formulations of iron therapy that are not indicated according to the criteria given above. Parenteral iron therapy is indicated in the following conditions:

  •  Contraindications of oral therapy such as severe gastrointestinal side effects of taking oral iron (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, teeth staining, epigastric distress)
  •  Non-cooperative patient 
  •  Cases that are seen for the first time during the last 8–10 weeks with severe anemia. 

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

 

Microcytic Hypochromic

(MCV <80 fl)

Normocytic Normochromic    

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Iron deficiency anemia

Sideroblastic anemia

Thalassemia

Lead toxicity

Acute blood loss

Anemia of chronic disease

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

 

Non-megaloblastic:

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Iron Deficiency Anemia

Dietary lack

  • Infants, who are at high risk due to the very small amounts of iron in milk. Human breast milk provides only about 0.3 mg/L of iron.
  • The impoverished, who can have suboptimal diets for socioeconomic reasons at any age
  • Older adults, who often have restricted diets with little meat because of limited income or poor dentition
  • Teenagers, who subsist on junk food

Impaired absorption

  • Sprue
  • Gastrectomy (Billroth II surgery)

Increased requirement

  • Growing infants, children, and adolescents
  • Premenopausal women, particularly during pregnancy.
  • Economically deprived women having multiple, closely spaced pregnancies are at exceptionally high risk.

Chronic blood loss

  • Menorrhagia
  • Carcinoma of the cecum
  • Hookworm infestation

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented at term with an ultrasound report suggesting a fetus in breech position with hyperextended neck. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a fetus with a hyperextended neck indicates that the fetus is in a stargazing position at term. The next best step in the management is to terminate by Cesarean section.

This hyperextension makes vaginal delivery and ECV dangerous as they can result in fetal cervical spine injury. And thus, the stargazing position is an indication for a Cesarean section.

Cesarean delivery of the breech fetus is indicated in the following:

  • Large fetus: >3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech
  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech

Note: Flying fetus is a term used when the fetus is in a transverse lie with a hyperextended neck.

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text:
A 23-year-old primigravida at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. She was diagnosed with gestational hypertension 2 weeks back. Lab values are as follows. Which of the following other laboratory findings would be most likely seen in this patient?

Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
Blood glucose and cholesterol: Normal
Peripheral smear: Hemolytic red blood cells
questions.solution:
The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, suggests a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Elevated aspartate transaminase (AST) would be most likely seen in this patient with HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is an acronym that stands for: 

  • Hemolysis
  • Elevated Liver enzymes 
  • Low Platelets

Microangiopathic hemolysis manifests as:

  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels (Option B)
  • Reduced haptoglobin levels
  • Schizocytosis, spherocytosis, and reticulocytosis on peripheral blood smear

Elevation of AST and ALT (liver enzymes) levels occurs due to periportal hemorrhagic necrosis in the liver. Furthermore, hemorrhagic infarcts can extend to form a subcapsular hematoma that stretches the Glisson capsule. This results in characteristic epigastric/right quadrant pain and tenderness. It can be diagnosed using a CT or MRI. 

HELLP syndrome can also be associated with other complications such as eclampsia, placental abruption, stroke, coagulopathy, and pulmonary edema. 

Option A: Markedly elevated bilirubin levels are not likely seen in HELLP syndrome which characteristically does not present with marked hepatic dysfunction unlike acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Patients with acute fatty liver of pregnancy are likely to present with marked elevations of AST and bilirubin, hypoglycemia and hypocholesterolemia.

The clinical and laboratory findings of acute liver diseases in pregnancy are as follows:

Disorders  HELLP syndrome Obstetric cholestasis Acute fatty liver of pregnancy Viral hepatitis
Onset in pregnancy Mid to late Late Late Variable
Differentiating features        - Pruritus  (elevated serum bile acids) Signs of liver failure  Fever
AST (U/L)  ≤300  ≤200 200-800 2000+
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 1-4 1-5 4-10 5-20
Platelets ↓↓  Normal ↓↓  ↓
Fibrinogen Normal Normal ↓↓↓ Normal
D-dimer ↑ Normal ↑ Normal
Prothrombin time Normal Normal ↑↑  ↑
Hemolysis  ↑↑ No ↑↑↑  No

questions.text:
Prompt surgical management would be indicated in a patient with Sheehan syndrome if there is _______.
  1. Significant visual loss
  2. Progressive visual loss
  3. Cranial nerve palsy
  4. Hypopituitarism
  5. Loss of consciousness
questions.solution:
Significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness are considered indications for urgent surgical decompression in patients with Sheehan syndrome (option B- 1, 2, 3, or 5).

Pituitary apoplexy is a hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it is called Sheehan syndrome. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of hemorrhage and infarction. 

Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.

The acute presentation of pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, is characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death.

Other features are:

  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Treatment is by hormone replacement: First, glucocorticoids and, later, thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin, and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement, or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out.

questions.text: If the fundal height of the uterus is 35 cm and the head is at -2 station, what is the approximate fetal weight?
questions.solution:
The approximate fetal weight is 3.5 kg.

Estimated fetal weight (EFW) from fundal height and station of the head is given by the Johnson formula:

  • If station is below ischial spine: EFW = [height(in cm)-11] x 155
  • If station is at or above ischial spine: EFW = [height(in cm)-12] x 155

The above formula gives the estimated fetal weight in grams.

The station of the head is zero if the presenting part is at the level of ischial spines.

The station is stated in negative values (-1, -2, etc) if the head is above ischial spines and in positive values (+1, +2, etc) if the head is below ischial spines.

Now, applying the formula;

  • Station of the head is -2 (above the ischial spine); height is 35 cm
  • EFW = (35-12)x 155 = 3565 grams = 3.56 kgs

Note: Shephard formula and Hadlock formula are used to measure fetal weight from USG by fetal biometry.

questions.text: The hysterosalpingography of a patient with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease shows bilateral fallopian tube blockage. Which of the following organisms has the highest propensity to cause this tube block?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis has the highest propensity to cause bilateral fallopian tube blockage.

Chlamydia infection remains asymptomatic in the endocervix and produces minimal symptoms, and therefore the infection goes unnoticed and untreated, but the damage it causes to the fallopian tube is five times higher than Neisseria gonorrhoea.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is usually a polymicrobial infection. The most common causes of PID are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 

Other organisms causing PID are Mycoplasma, E.coli, and anaerobes. PID commonly spreads as ascending infection along with sperms. Genital tuberculosis mostly has a hematogenous spread.

On ultrasound, a tubo-ovarian abscess may be seen which appears as a complex cystic adnexal or cul-de-sac mass with thick irregular walls and septations.

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis
 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient with a known case of rheumatic heart disease is in her first trimester. She has complaints of chest pain and syncope. Cardiac failure in pregnancy is most likely to occur in which of the following time period?
questions.solution:
Cardiac failure in pregnancy is most likely to occur during the immediate postpartum period.

Cardiac failure during pregnancy can occur mostly following delivery. It can also occur during labor and at around 30 weeks.

Advancing age, cardiac arrhythmias, history of previous heart failure, and other pregnancy risk factors such as anemia, infection, hypertension, and multiple pregnancies can cause cardiac failure. 

Features include breathlessness, syncope, chest pain, and nocturnal cough. Chest murmurs, cardiac enlargement, and arrhythmia may be present. Chest radiography reveals an enlarged heart, increased pulmonary markings, and enlargement of pulmonary veins.

Maternal cardiac risk predictors are [Mnemonic: NOPE]

N-NYHA class >2

O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2 OR Aortic valve area <1.5 cm2,   peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg.

P-Prior cardiac events before pregnancy

E-Ejection fraction <40%

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with an adnexal mass. CA-125 was slightly raised and LDH was elevated. Microscopy after tumor resection is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a 35-year-old woman presenting with adnexal mass with raised CA 125 and LDH and the given microscopy, suggests a diagnosis of dysgerminoma.

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma.

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. Beta hCG levels are raised only in 5% of women due to intermittent syncytiotrophoblast. However, serum LDH, placental alkaline phosphatase are used in monitoring individuals for disease recurrence. Dysgerminomas are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement.

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who is G2P1 in the 32nd week of gestation was found to have a blood pressure of 160/98 mmHg without proteinuria. Her BP recorded during the previous ANC visits were 144/92 mmHg and 150/96 mmHg during the 16th week and 24th week of gestation respectively. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is  ____.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is chronic hypertension because her blood pressure at the 16th week of gestation was >140/90mmHg. 

Gestational Hypertension

Pre-Eclampsia

Chronic Hypertension in pregnancy

Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

Previously known hypertensive or BP  >140/90mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation

No Proteinuria

Proteinuria present(>300 mg in 24 hrs urine or >30 mg/dl in the random urine sample or urine dipstick 1+)

No proteinuria

BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

BP does not come to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

 

  • Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as BP of >140/90 mmHg measured 2 times with at least 6-h interval.
  • Also, diastolic BP is determined by the disappearance of Korotkoff V sound (normally, in adults we take Korotkoff IV for measuring DBP).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida in her third trimester presented with a history of sudden onset of painless vaginal bleeding. On evaluation, a diagnosis of placenta previa was made. A decision was taken to manage her condition using the McAfee and Johnson regimen. Which of the following criteria should be met for the same?

1) Assured fetal well being

2) Duration of pregnancy > 37 weeks

3) No active vaginal bleeding 

4) Maternal hemoglobin > 10g%
questions.solution:
The patient has been diagnosed with placenta previa. The criteria which have to be met for the expectant management regimen proposed by McAfee and Johnson include assured fetal well-being, no active vaginal bleeding, and maternal hemoglobin > 10 g%. 

A patient with diagnosed placenta previa and duration of pregnancy >37 weeks cannot be managed expectantly. The aim of conservative management is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. Termination of expectant management is done at 37 weeks when the fetus is sufficiently mature to survive.

McAfee and Johnson expectant management regimen:

Prerequisites:

  • Availability of blood for transfusion 
  • Facilities for cesarean sections are available 

Selection of cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  1. Mother is hemodynamically stable (Hb >10 g% and/or hematocrit > 30%) 
  2. Duration of pregnancy < 37 weeks 
  3. No active vaginal bleeding 
  4. The fetus was normal on ultrasound and reactive on cardiotocography

Conduct of expectant treatment: 

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity 
  • Bed rest or pelvic rest
  • Periodic monitoring of mother for bleeding PV
  • Fetal surveillance with USG  
  • Tocolytics if contractions are present
  • Anti-D to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urinary pregnancy test presented with mild pain abdomen and slight bleeding per vaginum for 5 days. She was diagnosed with cervical pregnancy. Which of the following criteria is used for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cervical pregnancy can be diagnosed using Rubin's criteria.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where the implantation occurs in the cervical canal at the level of or below the internal os.

Rubin's criteria for pathological diagnosis of cervical pregnancies:

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

Transvaginal sonographic findings of cervical pregnancy include:

  • An hourglass uterine shape and ballooned cervical canal
  • Gestational tissue at the level of the cervix 
  • Absent intrauterine gestational tissue
  • A portion of the endocervical canal is interposed between the gestation and the endometrial canal.

Treatment: Medical management with methotrexate if vitals are stable and it is diagnosed in the first trimester. Surgical management with suction curettage or hysterectomy is done if vitals are unstable, bleeding uncontrolled, or if the gestation is advanced.

Prior to any procedure, uterine artery embolization, local methotrexate injection into the amnionic sac, ligation of the uterine arteries, or cerclage at the internal os to compress feeding vessels may be done to control bleeding.

The image below shows an ultrasonogram of cervical pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Spiegelberg’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall

Option B: Godin's sonographic criteria is for the diagnosis of a cesarean scar pregnancy

  • Empty uterine cavity
  • Empty cervical canal
  • A gestational sac in the anterior part of the uterine isthmus
  • Absence of healthy myometrium between the bladder and gestational sac

Option D: Studdiford criteria is used in the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy. It includes:

  • Presence of normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past injury/pregnancy.
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  • Presence of a pregnancy-related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation after primary tubal nidation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L1 woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with pruritus on the palms and soles for 2 weeks. She also had yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL. Alkaline phosphatase levels were elevated, and serum transaminase levels were normal. She also reports that she had similar complaints during the previous pregnancy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease occurring in the 2nd or 3rd trimester. It is characterized by pruritus (worse on palms and soles and at the night) and icterus. It is also known as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum.

Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment, but total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 4 to 5 mg/dL. Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated, but seldom exceed 250 U/L. Total and fasting serum bile acid concentrations are elevated. Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated. Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Management comprises antihistamines, topical emollients, cholestyramine, and ursodeoxycholic acid.

Other options:

Option B: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy manifests mostly in the last trimester of pregnancy with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, epigastric pain, and progressive jaundice. There may be hypertension, protein­uria, and edema. There is moderate to severe liver dysfunction with hypofi­brinogenemia, hypoalbuminemia, hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting times. Serum bilirubin level is usually <10 mg/dL, and serum transaminases are ele­vated but <1000 U/L.

Option C: Acute viral hepatitis is usually asymptomatic. When symptomatic, it presents with nausea, vomiting, and malaise, followed by jaundice. Low-grade fever may be present. Serum bilirubin rises, and transaminase levels vary.

Option D: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is commonly associated with obesity, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia­ syndrome. It is usually asymptomatic with elevated transaminases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal vasomotor symptoms. She is currently on treatment for hypertension and Alzheimer's disease. She is a known smoker, and her previous ultrasound reports indicate the presence of uterine fibroids.  Which among the following is a contraindication in her for starting hormone replacement therapy?
questions.solution:
The presence of uterine fibroids is a contraindication for HRT, as it may lead to a further increase in the size of the fibroids.

Indication for HRT is as follows:

  • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency
  • High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
  • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, 
  • Menopause caused by radiotherapy, chemotherapy

Contraindications:

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer, or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of the thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gall bladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

Diabetes, hypertension, or smoking are not contraindications for HRT, as long as they are regularly monitored.

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the antenatal ward at 35 weeks. Her BP is 170/110 mm Hg and her urine dipstick is 3+. She has a generalized seizure during the examination. Her airway is secured and now, what will be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Give a 4 g bolus of MgSO4 by slow IV injection
Give a 10 mg bolus IV injection of hydralazine

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a patient with eclampsia, where the first step of treatment is the establishment of the airway followed by oxygen inhalation.

The standard procedure for a patient with eclampsia is:

  • Call for extra help (communication)
  • Place the patient in a left lateral recumbent position
  • Maintain oral airway
  • O2 inhalation – non-breather mask; 10 L/minute
  • Commence IV lines; 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas
  • Foley catheter with a urometer
  • To monitor O2 saturation; pulse oximeter (SPO2 > 95%)
  • Control of seizures - MgSO4, (IV/IM regimens)
  • To monitor vitals; fetal status and magnesium toxicity
  • Control of hypertension - labetalol, hydralazine
  • Fluids - crystalloids (saline) or colloids (albumin/blood) <125 mL/h
  • Suction - oropharyngeal
  • Diuretics - pulmonary edema
  • Investigations to organize -
    • Blood - CBC, AST, ALT, LDH, creatinine, uric acid
    • Urine analysis - protein

MgSO4 regimens:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minutes followed by 
10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: A multiparous woman presents at 36 weeks of gestation. On examination, fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. In the fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in the pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. On the lateral grip, a soft, irregular breech is felt on one side of the midline. Identify the most common fetal position in the given presentation?
questions.solution:
The given examination findings are suggestive of a transverse lie. The most common fetal position in a transverse lie is dorso-anterior.

Transverse lie occurs when the long axis of the fetus lies perpendicularly to the maternal spine or centralized uterine axis.

The position of the fetus in a transverse lie is determined by the direction of the back, which is the denominator. The position may be:

  • Dorsoanterior, which is the most common. (60%)
  • Dorsoposterior, where the chance of fetal extension is common with increased risk of arm prolapse
  • Dorsosuperior 
  • Dorsoinferior

According to the position of the head, the fetal position is termed right or left, the left one being more common.

Abdominal examination findings:

On inspection, the uterus looks broader and is often asymmetrical. It does not maintain the pyriform shape.

Palpation:

  • Fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea.
  • Fundal grip: Fetal pole (breech or head) is not palpable.
  • Lateral grip: A smooth, hard, and globular head is felt on one side. A soft, broad, and irregular breech is felt on the other side.
    • In dorso-anterior: The back is felt anteriorly across the long axis 
    • In dorso-posterior: Irregular small parts are felt anteriorly
  • Pelvic grip: The lower pole of the uterus is empty.

questions.text: Pelvic examination of a patient with post-menopausal bleeding shows a growth in the vagina. A biopsy reveals that the growth is endometrial adenocarcinoma. Surgery is performed. Distant metastases are absent. What is the stage of her cancer?
questions.solution:
Carcinoma endometrium involving the vagina with absent distant metastasis is likely to be in Stage 3B.

Surgical staging of Ca endometrium with total abdominal hysterectomy+bilateral salpingoophorectomy+lymphadenectomy is the cornerstone of treatment. Thus, further management is mainly postoperative.

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

Related Pearl: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant
IV
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

*This pearl is in line with the FIGO 2010 guidelines. It will be updated according to the FIGO 2023 guidelines after an official treatment guideline is released.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida woman at 34 weeks of gestation is reported to have an amniotic fluid index of 4 cm. Which of the following fetal anomaly can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
An amniotic fluid index(AFI) of 4 cm is suggestive of oligohydramnios which can be associated with renal agenesis.

Oligohydramnios is a condition where there is decreased production of amniotic fluid. Sonographically, it is defined when the single deepest pocket of liquor is <2 cm or when the amniotic fluid index (AFI) is less than 5 cm (less than 5 percentile).

The fetus begins producing urine between 8 - 11 weeks of gestation. However, it does not become a major part of the composition of amniotic fluid until the second trimester. For this reason, fetuses with kidney abnormalities do not become evident until after 18 weeks of gestation. 

Causes of Oligohydraminios:

  • Placental abnormalities: Amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta)
  • Maternal complications leading to uteroplacental insufficiency: pre-eclampsia, vascular disease
  • Renal Anomalies:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • The infantile form of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney dis­ease
    • Fetal bladder outlet obstruction - posterior urethral valves, urethral atresia, or stenosis
  • Complex fetal anomalies: persistent cloaca and sireno­melia (mermaid syndrome).
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Drugs: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, NSAIDs when taken in the 2nd or 3rd trimester

Consequently, polyhydramnios is defined as a deepest vertical pocket of more than 8 cm or an AFI of more than 24 cm. There are various mechanisms that can lead to polyhydramnios such as: 

  • Maternal causes
    • Diabetes(Overt diabetes/Gestational diabetes)
    • Cardiac diseases
    • Renal Diseases
  • Fetal causes
    • Neural tube defects
    • Anencephaly
    • Cleft lip/palate, micrognathia
    • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
    • Esophageal and duodenal atresia
    • Aneuploidy
    • Hydrops fetalis due to Rh alloimmunization, nonimmune hydrops, cardiothoracic anomalies, fetal cirrhosis and fetal TORCH infections, parvovirus B19 infection
    • Twin pregnancy, Twin to Twin transfusion syndrome
    • Bartter syndrome
    • Sacrococcygeal teratoma
    • High-output cardiac states
  • Placental causes
    • Chorangioma of placenta
       

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal
  • Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)
  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • NSAIDs
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Overt diabetes
  • Gestational diabetes
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Liver failure

Fetal
  • Fetal anomalies
  • Renal agenesis
  • Urethral defects
    • Posterior valve
    • Obstructive uropathy

 
  • Multiple gestation
  • Neural tube defects
  • Abdominal wall defects
  • Cleft palate
  • Neck masses
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Aneuploidy
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • TTTS

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: An anxious pregnant woman came to you for a second opinion with the report of her biochemical screening tests. An increased level of  human chorionic gonadotropin(hCG), as compared to normal pregnancy hCG levels, can be seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) are decreased in ectopic pregnancy when compared to the level of hCG in normal intrauterine pregnancy. 

In comparison to hCG levels in normal pregnancy, increased levels of hCG are found in:

  • Hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma
  • Trisomy 21 fetus
  • Multiple pregnancies

Decreased levels of hCG as compared to normal pregnancy hCG levels are found in:

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Spontaneous abortion

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a glycoprotein. It can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8–9 days postfertilization. Maximum levels in blood and urine are found between 60 - 70 days of pregnancy. It disappears from the circulation within 2 weeks following delivery.

hCG is chemically and functionally similar to the pituitary luteinizing hormone (LH). The α subunit is biochemically similar to LH, FSH (follicular stimulating hormone), and TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) whereas the β subunit is relatively unique to hCG.

Functions of hCG are:

  • It stimulates the secretion of progesterone by the corpus luteum during pregnancy
  • Rescue and maintenance of corpus luteum till 6 weeks of pregnancy
  • It stimulates Leydig cells of the male fetus to produce testosterone in conjunction with fetal pituitary gonadotropins
  • It inhibits the maternal processes of immune rejection of the fetus as a homograft.
  • Stimulates both adrenal and placental steroidogenesis.
  • Stimulates maternal thyroid because of its thyrotropic activity.
  • Promotes secretion of relaxin from the corpus luteum.

Related Pearl: Beta hCG in pregnancy

The pattern of beta hCG :

First detectable in plasma 7 to 9 days post-LH surge
          ⇓
Doubles every 2 days
          ⇓
Peaks at 8 to 10 weeks of gestation(~100 IU/mL)
          ⇓
Begins to decline at 10 to 12 weeks
          ⇓
Plateau at 16 weeks till term
 
  • Higher maternal plasma hCG levels- Multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis, gestational trophoblastic disease, Down syndrome.
  • Lower hCG plasma levels -early pregnancy wastage and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the period after fertilization during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins?
questions.solution:
The period after fertilization, during which if division takes place, can result in conjoined twins, is >13 days.
