The proposed mechanisms are:

  • Incomplete splitting of one embryo into two 
  • Fusion of a portion of one embryo from a monozygotic pair onto the other. 

Types of monozygotic twinning:

Time of division after fertilization                        Type of twin                    
0 - 4 days (morula)    Dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA)
4 - 8 days (blastocyst)    Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA)
8 - 12 days (implanted blastocyst)    Monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA)
>13 days (formed embryonic disc)    Conjoined twins

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text:
A 35-year-old primigravida comes to the clinic with the results of her second-trimester prenatal screening tests. She is at 16-weeks gestation and has not taken any prenatal vitamins. She has a history of epilepsy on medications. She has no new complaints today. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows the symphysiofundal height to be 17cm and fetal heart sounds are heard. The results of her laboratory tests are given below.
Test Value Median Value and 95% CI
MSAFP 93 30.9 (30.07 - 31.73)
Unconjugated estriol 4.9 4.95 (4.85 - 5.04)
Total hCG 12.2 12.1 (11.40 - 12.79)

What is the next step in management of her condition?

choices.text: Repeat measurement of MSAFP at a later date

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of neural tube defects that could be attributed to the patient's lack of prenatal care. All pregnant women should be started on prophylactic folic acid in order to prevent the development of neural tube defects. This patient is particularly at higher risk, because of the use of her history of epilepsy. Patients who are taking enzyme-inducing anticonvulsants, such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, primidone, and phenobarbital, which are known to decrease folate levels, and valproic acid which may interfere with folate metabolism need to take higher doses of folic acid. 

MSAFP is a screening test. If it is raised, it should be followed by a diagnostic test and the most preferred test is targeted sonography.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • It is the major serum protein in the embryo and fetus.
  • Its concentration increases steadily in both fetal serum and amnionic fluid until 13 weeks gestation, after which, levels rapidly decline. Conversely, AFP is found in steadily increasing quantities in maternal serum after 12 weeks.
  • Defects in the fetal integument, such as neural tube and ventral wall defects, permit AFP to leak into the amnionic fluid, resulting in dramatically increased maternal serum AFP levels.
  • Maternal serum AFP screening is generally performed from 15 through 20 weeks.

Note: Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for amniotic fluid AFP measurement. It was once considered the standard for the diagnosis of open neural tube disorders, and now it has been replaced in most centers by targeted sonography.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman was evaluated for uterine bleeding. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a swiss-cheese pattern. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Swiss-cheese pattern in histopathological examination of endometrium in a premenopausal woman is suggestive of metropathia haemorrhagica. It is characterized by massive painless vaginal bleeding.

Metropathia haemorrhagica/ Cystic glandular hyperplasia/ Schroeder's disease: It is a specialized type of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding, usually seen in premenopausal women (40 to 45 years). Typically patients complain of continuous painless vaginal bleeding. It can occur after 6-8 weeks of amenorrhea or can be preceded by a period of menorrhagia.

The uterus becomes bulky due to symmetrical enlargement. The endometrium is thickened, and thin polypi project into the uterine cavity. There is also mild degree of myohyperplasia of the uterine wall. Ovaries may contain cysts, but the corpus luteum is absent.

Microscopy reveals:

  • Swiss cheese pattern of cystic glandular hyperplasia.
  • Absence of secretory endometrium- since the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium. so the cork-screw glands are not seen.
  • Endometrium shows superficial necrosis resembling that of the first day of menstruation.

If the patient has a preceding history of amenorrhea, it can be confused with ectopic pregnancy or abortion. However, painless vaginal bleeding is the clue to differentiation.

questions.text: The risk of which complication of suction evacuation is reduced by the usage of these plastic instruments?
questions.solution:
Karman’s type suction cannulas made of plastic, reduce the risk of uterine perforation during suction evacuation procedures.

There are different sizes of the Karman's suction cannula. The size to be used depends on the duration of the pregnancy in weeks. Size 4-7 mm can be used for 4-6 week period of gestation, size 5-10 mm can be used for 7-9 weeks, and 8-12 mm can be used for 9-12 weeks. The plastic cannula allows visualization of the products being evacuated.

Suction evacuation is a procedure by means of which products of conception are sucked out of the uterus with a cannula attached to a suction apparatus. 

Indications:  

  • 1st-trimester medical termination of pregnancy 
  • Inevitable abortion 
  • Recent incomplete abortion 
  • Hydatidiform mole 

Procedure: 

  1. Vaginal examination is done to assess the size and position of the uterus and the state of the cervix
  2. Posterior vaginal speculum held by an assistant
  3. Grasp the anterior lip of the cervix with an Allis forceps
  4. Introduce a uterine sound to determine the length of the cavity and position of the uterus
  5. Dilate the cervix if required until one size less than that of the suction cannula
  6. Administer intravenous methergine 0.2mg
  7. Insert suction cannula with the tip in the middle of the uterine cavity
  8. Increase the pressure to 400-600mmHg. Move the cannula up and down and rotate it 360 degrees with the pressure on. 
  9. Inspect the suction bottle of products of conception and blood loss.
  10. Regulate the suction with a finger over the hole at the base of the cannula
  11. Break the vacuum before withdrawing the cannula
  12. Curette the uterus at the end of the suction and reintroduce the cannula to remove remnants. 

Suction is stopped when no more material is sucked out, there is gripping of the cannula by the uterus, a grating sensation, or appearance of bubbles in the cannula. 

Complications of suction evacuation:

Immediate:

  • Excessive hemorrhage due to incomplete evacuation or atonic uterus.
  • Injury due to cervical lacerations of varying degree which may lead to the formation of a broad ligament hematoma and uterine perforation. 
  • Shock due to excessive blood loss, anesthesia complications, or cervical shock—vasovagal syncope due to cervical stimulation. 
  • Perforation—injury to major blood vessels, bowel or bladder
  • Sepsis—endometritis, myometritis, pelvic peritonitis. 
  • Hematometra 
  • Increased morbidity
  • Continuation of pregnancy (failure) – 1%.

Late: 

  • Pelvic inflammation 
  • Infertility 
  • Cervical incompetence 
  • Uterine synechiae
  • Subsequent pregnancy risks- preterm labor, ectopic pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Which of the following increases during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Fibrinogen increases during pregnancy.

All clotting factors increase in pregnancy except factor 11,13. Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state.

Hematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factor 11,13) and fibrinogen levels are also increased.
  • The viscosity of blood doesn’t increase since plasma volume increases more in comparison to red cell volume, it merely decreases whole blood viscosity.
  • Clotting time is unaffected.
  • The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia (may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and women are asymptomatic).
  • Fibrinolytic activity remains depressed till about 15 minutess after pregnancy

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is screaming in pain while being wheeled into the labor room at 2 am. On examination, her cervix is well-effaced and is 4 cm dilated. What is the preferred anesthetic technique to ensure this patient has a painless labour?
questions.solution:
A lumbar epidural is the preferred anesthetic technique to ensure that this patient has painless labor.

For adequate pain relief, the sensory block of T10-L1 is required during the first stage of labor, and S2-S4 is required during the second stage. The epidural catheter placed at L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspace sufficiently provides T10–S5 neural blockade.

Maternal hydration has to be ensured with normal saline or Hartmann's solution infusion before epidural blockade is commenced. The patient's heart rate, blood pressure, and fetal heart rate have to be monitored every 15 minutes following the induction of anesthesia, and maternal hypotension has to be treated promptly.  

Contraindications of epidural analgesia include neurological diseases, maternal coagulopathy or anticoagulant therapy, hypovolemia, supine hypotension, and skin infection at the injection site.

Complications of epidural analgesia include hypotension due to sympathetic blockade, post-spinal headache, pain at the injection site, and injury to nerves. 

Option A: Pudendal nerve block is given in the second stage of labor just before delivery of the baby to provide analgesia to the vulva and anus​. It is mostly used for forceps and vaginal breech deliveries. However, it has no effect on the pain of contractions. It is also given before repair of episiotomy or perineal lacerations.

Option B: Spinal anesthesia for labor analgesia has the advantage of a rapid and reliable onset of the neural blockade, and it is technically easier to administer compared to epidural analgesia. However, repeated intrathecal injections may be required for prolonged labor, thus increasing the risk of post-dural puncture headache.

Option C: Caudal epidural is largely avoided for pain relief in obstetrics. It requires large volumes of a local anesthetic to anesthetize upper lumbar and lower thoracic dermatomes to provide adequate labor analgesia. Though rare, accidental puncture of the fetus is a possibility.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman presents at 34 weeks gestation with bleeding per vaginum (PV). She had 3 episodes of spotting during this pregnancy, which resolved on their own. She has no pain. On examination, vitals are stable and the fetus is found to be in transverse lie with a fetal heart rate of 140 beats/min. What is the gold standard investigation to diagnose the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This woman’s history is suggestive of placenta previa, for which the gold standard investigation would be an MRI. The sagittal images of the MRI best demonstrate the relationship of the placenta to the internal cervical os, although it is not required in most instances.

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. Placenta previa and abruptio placenta together account for 70% of the cases of antepartum hemorrhage.

Other Options:

A transvaginal sonogram (TVS) is more accurate to assess placenta praevia, as the transabdominal sonogram overdiagnoses it.

Note: Transvaginal sonogram (TVS) is the most common investigation, but MRI is the gold standard investigation to diagnose placenta previa since it demonstrates the relationship of the placenta to the internal cervical os.

questions.text: A lady in her late 40s came to the hospital with chief complaints of discomfort in the pelvic area, abdominal bloating, and quickly feeling full when eating. She also had a history of weight loss,  changes in bowel habits such as constipation, and a frequent need to urinate. An abnormality associated with the BRCA gene is suspected. Identify the false statement about the BRCA genes related to the underlying condition.

choices.text: BRCA 2 is more carcinogenic than BRCA 1
BRCA 1 is associated with hereditary breast ovarian cancer syndrome

questions.solution:
Option A is a false statement because BRCA 1 is more carcinogenic than BRCA 2, not vice-versa.

The underlying condition based on the given non-specific clinical features is ovarian carcinoma which is considerably more common and tends to develop at an earlier age in women with a germline BRCA1 pathogenic variant as compared to women with a germline BRCA2 pathogenic variant. 

  • 5–10% of malignant ovarian tumours are genetic.
  • BRCA 1 gene is on chromosome 17q.
  • BRCA 2 gene is on chromosome 13q.
  • BRCA 1 is associated with hereditary breast ovarian cancer syndrome.

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma Low risk Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia Not associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated Not associated
